{{DISPLAYTITLE:''National Herald'' scam}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} The '''''National Herald'' scam''' is an ongoing case in a Delhi court filed by Indian economist and politician [[Subramanian Swamy]] against politicians [[Sonia Gandhi]] and [[Rahul Gandhi]], their companies and associated persons.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/delhi-court-summons-sonia-rahul-in-national-herald-case/article6151487.ece |title=Delhi court summons Sonia, Rahul in National Herald case |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=27 June 2014}}</ref> As per the complaint filed in the court of the Metropolitan Magistrate, Associated Journals Limited (AJL) took an interest-free loan of {{INRConvert|90.25|c}} from [[Indian National Congress]]. It is alleged that the loan was not repaid.<ref>{{Citation|title = Section 269T in The Income- Tax Act, 1995|url = http://indiankanoon.org/doc/1517955/|website = indiankanoon.org|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> A closely held company, Young Indian, was incorporated in November 2010 with a capital of {{INRConvert|50|l}} and it acquired almost all the shareholding of AJL and all its properties (alleged to be worth {{INRConvert|5000|c}}).<ref name="The Hindu"/> Swamy alleged criminal misappropriation by both Sonia Gandhi and Rahul Gandhi. The courts have determined that a prima face case has been established in the matter.
==Associated Journals Limited== Associated Journals Limited (AJL) is an unlisted public company limited by shares, incorporated on 20 November 1937, with its registered office at Herald House, 5-A, Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg, New Delhi. It was the brainchild of [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] but it was never his personal property as it was started with the support of about 5,000 freedom fighters who became shareholders of AJL. The company's capital was {{INRConvert|5|l}} divided into 2,000 preferential shares worth {{INRConvert|100}} each and 30,000 ordinary (equity) shares worth {{INRConvert|10}} each. Apart from Nehru, AJL's Memorandum of Association was signed by stalwarts such as [[Purushottam Das Tandon]], Acharya [[Narendra Dev]], [[Kailash Nath Katju]], [[Rafi Ahmad Kidwai]], Krishna Dutt Paliwal and [[Govind Ballabh Pant]]. The company did not belong to any particular person, nor did it want to be associated with any business except news. AJL had 1,057 shareholders as of 29 September 2010<ref name="The Indian Express">{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/national-herald-case-loan-write-off-conflict-of-interest-benefiting-takeover-by-family/|title=National Herald case: Loan write-off, conflict of interest, benefiting takeover by family|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]|date=9 December 2015}}</ref> as per the annual return filed by the company with the Registrar of Companies.
[[Motilal Vora]] has been the chairman and managing director of AJL since 22 March 2002.<ref name="indianexpress.com">{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/explained/deals-at-national-herald-who-got-what-when-how-2/|title=Deals at National Herald: Who got what, when, how|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]| date=10 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="auto"/> The company had incurred losses<ref name="The Indian Express"/> before its holdings were transferred to Young India in 2011.<ref name=livemint /><ref>{{citation|title=Full text: Sonia, Rahul accused of grabbing Rs 1,600 cr property|url=http://firstpost.com/politics/full-text-swamy-accuses-rahul-sonia-of-fraud-511434.html|date=1 November 2012|publisher=[[Firstpost]]}}</ref>
AJL published the [[The National Herald (India)|''National Herald'' newspaper]] in English, ''[[Qaumi Awaz]]'' in Urdu and ''Navjeevan'' in Hindi until 2008. AJL also owns real estate property in various cities including New Delhi, Lucknow, Bhopal, Mumbai, Indore, Patna and Panchkula.<ref name="The Hindu">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/the-nittygritty-of-the-national-herald-case/article7967367.ece|title=The nitty-gritty of 'The National Herald' case|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|date=10 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="indianexpress.com"/> The value of the real estate owned by AJL is estimated to be at {{INRConvert|50|b}}.<ref name="The Hindu"/> The properties of AJL include Herald House, a six-storey building with around 10,000 sq metre office space.<ref>{{citation|title=How National Herald newspaper funds Rahul and Sonia Gandhi's Young Indian|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-how-national-herald-newspaper-funds-rahul-and-sonia-gandhi-s-young-indian-1999011|publisher=[[Daily News and Analysis]]|date=2 July 2014|location=[[New Delhi]]}}</ref>
On 21 January 2016 the AJL in its meeting in [[Lucknow]] decided to relaunch the three dailies, National Herald and its sister publications, Quami Awaz and Navjivan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/relaunch-of-national-herald-is-still-a-long-way-off/article8835995.ece|title=Relaunch of National Herald is still a long way off|publisher=[[The Hindu]]| date=12 July 2016}}</ref>
===Other shareholders allege their shares usurped=== After the Delhi High Court dismissed the appeal of Sonia Gandhi and others against the summons issued by the trial court, many shareholders of AJL have alleged that no notice was served on them by AJL for any meeting of the shareholders and that the shares held by their fathers have been transferred by AJL to Young Indian fraudulently without their consent in December 2010. These shareholders include prominent individuals such as former law minister [[Shanti Bhushan]] and former chief justice of Allahabad and Madras High Courts [[Markandey Katju]].<ref name = shareholders>{{citation|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/ajl-did-not-inform-us-or-obtain-approval-for-equity-transfer-say-shareholders|title=AJL did not inform us or obtain approval for equity transfer, say shareholders|date=12 December 2015|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref>
==Young Indian== Young Indian is a private company limited by guarantee, incorporated on 23 November 2010 with a capital of {{INRConvert|5|l}}<ref name="The Hindu"/> and with its registered office at 5A, Herald House, Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg, Delhi. On 13 December 2010, [[Rahul Gandhi]] was appointed director of Young Indian while [[Sonia Gandhi]] joined the board of directors on 22 January 2011.<ref name="indianexpress.com"/> Of the company's shares, 76 percent are jointly held by Sonia Gandhi and Rahul Gandhi, and the remaining 24 percent are held by [[Indian National Congress|Congress]] leaders [[Motilal Vora]] and [[Oscar Fernandes]] (12 percent each).<ref name=livemint>{{citation|title=Real estate at core of Associated Journals controversy|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/bUEeUUtEit7aZjGNZEK6ZL/Real-estate-at-core-of-Associated-Journals-controversy.html|publisher=Live Mint|date=14 November 2012|location=[[New Delhi]]/[[Bangalore]]}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/what-is-the-national-herald-case-all-about/1/541733.html|title=What is the National Herald case all about?|publisher=[[India Today]]| date=8 December 2015}}</ref> It is described by Rahul Gandhi's office as a "not-for-profit company" which does have commercial operations.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/rahul-threatens-to-sue-subramanian-swamy/article4055087.ece|title=Rahul threatens to sue Subramanian Swamy|publisher=[[The Hindu]]| date=2 November 2012}}</ref>
==Case==
On 1 November 2012, [[Subramanian Swamy]] filed a private complaint in a court in Delhi alleging that both [[Sonia Gandhi]] and [[Rahul Gandhi]] have committed fraud and [[land grabbing]] worth {{INRConvert|16|b}} by acquiring a publicly limited company called Associated Journals Limited (AJL) through their owned private company, Young Indian.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lobis.nic.in/ddir/dhc/SUG/judgement/07-12-2015/SUG07122015CRLMM33322014.pdf |title=CRL.M.C.3332/2014 & Crl.M.A.11550/2014 |publisher=lobis.nic.in|date=7 December 2015}}</ref> He also claimed that, through this fraud, they had got the publication rights of the ''[[The National Herald (India)|National Herald]]'' and ''Quami Awaz'' newspapers, with real estate properties in Delhi and Uttar Pradesh. He alleged that the acquired properties were given by the government only for the purposes of publishing newspapers, but were used for running a passport office with rental income amounting to millions of rupees.<ref>{{cite web|author=New Delhi, 1 Nov 2012, DHNS: |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/289449/swamy-accuses-sonia-rahul-property.html |title=Swamy accuses Sonia, Rahul of property fraud |work=Deccan Herald |date=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Sanjay Singh |url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/swamy-does-a-kejriwal-targets-sonia-rahul-for-landgrab-511644.html |title=Swamy does a Kejriwal, targets Sonia & Rahul for landgrab |publisher=Firstpost |date=1 November 2012}}</ref>
His complaint in the court further alleges that, on 26 February 2011, AJL approved the transfer<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/what-is-the-national-herald-case-all-about/1/541733.html|title=What is the National Herald case all about?|publisher=[[India Today]]| date=8 December 2015}}</ref> of an [[Unsecured debt|unsecured loan]] of {{INRConvert|90|c}} from the [[All India Congress Committee]] at zero interest{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} with all ninety million (9 crore) of the company's shares of {{INRConvert|10}} each to Young Indian.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/rahul-threatens-to-sue-subramanian-swamy/article4055087.ece|title=Rahul threatens to sue Subramanian Swamy|publisher=[[The Hindu]]| date=2 November 2012}}</ref> Swamy argued that it is illegal for a political party to lend money for commercial purposes as per Section 29A to C of the [[Representation of the People Act (India)|Representation of the People Act, 1951]], and Section 13A of Income-tax Act, 1961, and demanded investigation by the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI) and the de-recognition of the Indian National Congress party for using public money.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Swamy-seeks-Congress-de-recognition-party-says-Herald-emotional-issue/Article1-954171.aspx |title=Swamy seeks Congress' de-recognition; party says Herald emotional issue |work=Hindustan Times |date=3 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313040054/http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/newdelhi/swamy-seeks-congress-de-recognition-party-says-herald-emotional-issue/article1-954171.aspx |archivedate=2014-03-13 }}</ref> On 2 November 2012, the party responded that the loan was given only for reviving the ''National Herald'' newspaper with no commercial interest.<ref>{{cite web|author=Smita Gupta |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/congress-to-revive-national-herald-challenges-swamy-to-take-it-to-court/article4058571.ece |title=Congress to revive National Herald, challenges Swamy to take it to court |work=The Hindu |date=2 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=Press Trust of India |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/swamy-to-move-court-against-ec/article4073917.ece |title=Swamy to move court against EC |work=The Hindu |date=7 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/ec-orders-probe-against-rahul-gandhi-for-wrong-information/305996-37-64.html |title=EC orders probe against Rahul Gandhi for 'wrong information' about his assets |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date=17 November 2012}}</ref>
The hearing of the criminal proceedings case was taken up by the magistrate on various dates while the defendants opposed the petition and asked the magistrate to dismiss it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2013/03/16/subramanian-swamy-s-victory-against-sonia-rahul-gandhi-1173225.html|title=Subramanian Swamy's victory against Sonia, Rahul Gandhi|publisher=One India| date=16 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/nation/national-herald-acquisition-delhi-court-summons-roc-to-testify-records.html|title=NATIONAL HERALD ACQUISITION: DELHI COURT SUMMONS ROC TO TESTIFY RECORDS|publisher=dailypioneer| date=29 April 2014}}</ref> The court finally observed that ''[[prima facie]]'' evidence against all the accused was found. The court issued summons to the defendants to appear in the court to defend themselves against all the allegations made in Swamy's complaint.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/court-summons-sonia-gandhi-rahul-in-national-herald-land-grab-case_942922.html|title=Court summons Sonia Gandhi, Rahul in National Herald land grab case|publisher=ZEE NEWS | date=26 June 2014}}</ref>
On 26 June 2014, Metropolitan Magistrate Ms. Gomati Manocha summoned Sonia Gandhi, Rahul Gandhi, Motilal Vora, Oscar Fernandes, Suman Dubey and Satyan Pitroda to appear in the court on 7 August 2014. She said that according to the evidence so far, "it appears that YIL was in fact created as a sham or a cloak to convert public money to personal use" to acquire control over {{INRConvert|20|b}} worth of AJL assets. The court noted that all accused persons had allegedly acted "in consortium with each other to achieve the said nefarious purpose/design".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/what-is-the-national-herald-case-all-about/1/541733.html|title=What is the National Herald case all about?|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/explained/national-herald-case-where-the-matter-stands/|title=National Herald case explained: Everything you need to know|date=8 December 2015|work=The Indian Express}}</ref>
==Appeal in Delhi High Court and Supreme Court==
The defendants appealed in the [[Delhi High Court]] against the summons issued by the magistrate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/National-Herald-case-Delhi-HC-stays-criminal-proceedings-against-Sonia-Gandhi-Rahul-Gandhi/articleshow/39756755.cms|title=National Herald case: Delhi HC stays criminal proceedings against Sonia Gandhi, Rahul Gandhi|publisher=TIMES OF INDIA | date=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/national-herald-case-relief-for-sonia-rahul-delhi-hc-stays-summons-till-august-13_952910.html|title=National Herald case: Relief for Sonia, Rahul, Delhi HC stays summons till August 13|publisher=ZEE NEWS | date=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/national-herald-case-what-you-should-know/20151209.htm|title=National Herald case: What you should know|publisher=[[Rediff.com]]| date=9 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/explained/national-herald-case-where-the-matter-stands/|title=National Herald case explained: Everything you need to know|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]| date=10 December 2015}}</ref> On 1 August 2014, Swamy was served notice to file reply in the High Court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/national-herald-case-delhi-high-court-serves-notice-to-subramanian-swamy-congress-sonia-gandhi-rahul-gandhi/1/375130.html|title=National Herald case: Delhi High Court serves notice to Subramanian Swamy|publisher=INDIA TODAY | date=1 August 2014}}</ref> On 28 August 2014, the metropolitan court fixed 9 December 2014 for the next hearing of the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/national-herald-case-delhi-trial-court-to-hear-case-on-9-december-1686177.html|title=National Herald case: Delhi trial court to hear case on 9 December|publisher=FIRST POST | date=28 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.oneindia.in/india/court-defers-hearing-in-national-herald-case-1510868.html|title=Court defers hearing in National Herald case|publisher=ONE INDIA | date=28 August 2014}}</ref> On 12 January 2015, the judge of the Delhi High Court recused himself from hearing the case and directed that the petitions be directed before an appropriate bench.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/national-herald-case-judge-recuses-from-hearing-sonia-gandhi-rahul-gandhi-plea/|title=National Herald case: Judge recuses from hearing Sonia Gandhi, Rahul Gandhi plea|publisher=THE INDIAN EXPRESS| date=12 January 2015}}</ref>
On 27 January 2015, the [[Supreme Court of India]] directed Swamy to make a case for speedy trial in the Delhi High Court which was hearing the appeal of Sonia Gandhi and others against the summons issued to them by the trial court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/national-herald-case-sc-directs-subramanian-swamy-approach-delhi-hc-2067027.html|title=National Herald case: SC directs Subramanian Swamy to approach Delhi HC|publisher=FIRST POST| date=27 January 2015}}</ref> On plea by Sonia Gandhi and others, defendants requested that the Chief Justice reassign the case to Justice Sunil Gaur, who had recused himself earlier. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Congress-had-opposed-transfer-of-case-insisted-on-Gaur/articleshow/50130121.cms|title=Congress had opposed transfer of case, insisted on Gaur|work=The Times of India}}</ref>
On 1 August 2014, the [[Enforcement Directorate]] initiated a probe to discover if there was any [[Money laundering#India|money laundering]] in the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/national-herald-case-trouble-for-sonia-rahul-as-ed-begins-preliminary-probe_951680.html|title=National Herald case: Trouble for Sonia, Rahul as ED begins preliminary probe|publisher=ZEE NEWS | date=1 August 2014}}</ref> On 18 September 2015, it was reported that the Enforcement Directorate had reopened the investigation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/politics/enforcement-directorate-reopens-national-herald-case-involving-sonia-and-rahul-gandhi-which-was-closed-in-august-1102471.html|title=Enforcement Directorate reopens National Herald case involving Sonia and Rahul Gandhi, which was closed in August|publisher=IBN Live| date=18 September 2015}}</ref>
On 7 December 2015, the Delhi High Court dismissed the appeals of Sonia Gandhi, Rahul Gandhi and five others which included [[Motilal Vora]], [[Oscar Fernandes]], Suman Dubey and [[Sam Pitroda|Satyan Pitroda]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/national-herald-case-court-directs-sonia-rahul-to-appear-on-dec-19/article7961353.ece?ref=relatedNews|title=Sonia, Rahul to appear in court on December 19, Congress disrupts Parliament|publisher=[[The Hindu]]| date=8 December 2015}}</ref> and ordered them to appear in person before the trial court on 9 December.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/national-herald-case-loan-write-off-conflict-of-interest-benefiting-takeover-by-family/|title=National Herald case: Loan write-off, conflict of interest, benefiting takeover by family|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]| date=9 December 2014}}</ref> The Delhi High Court said in its 7 December 2015 judgment noted "criminal intent."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/national-herald-case-where-are-the-296-missing-shareholders-of-ajl-115121200283_1.html|title=The mystery of the missing 296 AJL shareholders|author=N Sundaresha Subramanian|date=12 December 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
On 12 February 2016 the Supreme Court granted exemption to all the five accused in the case from personal appearances while refusing to quash proceedings against them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/national-herald-case-sc-exempts-gandhis-from-personal-appearance/article8227320.ece|title=National Herald case: SC exempts Gandhis from personal appearance|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|date=12 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/india/national-herald-case-breather-for-sonia-rahul-as-sc-expunges-objectionable-parts-of-hc-order_1854991.html|title=National Herald case: Breather for Sonia, Rahul as SC expunges objectionable parts of HC order|publisher=[[Zee News]]|date=12 February 2016}}</ref> Later on 12 July 2016 the Delhi High Court set aside the trial court judgement allowing examination of balance sheets and other documents of Congress party and other two companies, the AJL and Young Indian.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://delhihighcourt.nic.in/writereaddata/upload/Announcements/AnnouncementFile_BE5FNPPV.PDF|title=J- 2 PRONOUNCEMENT OF JUDGEMENTS(APPLET. JURISDICTION),1.CRL.M.C 671/2016,2.CRL.M.C. 672/2016, 3.CRL.M.C. 1317/2016, 4. CRL.M.C.1319/2016, 5. CRL.M.C.1321/2016|publisher=[[Delhi High Court]]|date=12 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/national-herald-case-sonia-rahul-gandhi-subramanian-swamy/1/712945.html|title=National Herald case: Relief for Sonia, Rahul as HC denies documents to Subramanian Swamy|publisher=[[India Today]]| date=12 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/national-herald-case-hc-sets-aside-trial-court-order-summoning-documents-116071200605_1.html|title=National Herald case: HC sets aside trial court order summoning documents|publisher=[[Business Standard]]| date=12 July 2016}}</ref> The next hearing in the court is scheduled on 20 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/will-file-fresh-application-in-herald-case-swamy-to-court-116071600485_1.html|title=Will file fresh application in National Herald case: Subramanian Swamy to court|publisher=[[Business Standard]]| date=16 July 2016}}</ref>
== Trial in the magistrate's court== On 7 December 2015, the Delhi High Court ordered Sonia Gandhi, Rahul Gandhi and five others to appear in person before the trial court on 9 December. They did not appear in the court and, on their lawyers' request, the trial court ordered them to appear before him in person on 19 December. He disallowed their request for exemption from personal appearance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/national-herald-case-delhi-court-asks-sonia-rahul-gandhi-to-appear-on-dec-19/|title=National Herald case: Gandhis to appear before court on Dec 19, Rahul says it's 'vendetta' politics|date=9 December 2015|work=The Indian Express}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/516282/national-herald-case-sonia-rahul.html|title=National Herald Case: Sonia and Rahul to appear in court on Dec 19|work=Deccan Herald}}</ref> On 19 December 2015 the Patiala House court granted bail to all but one and ordered them to appear in the court on the date of next hearing 20 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/sonia-rahul-get-bail-in-national-herald-case-in-less-than-5-minutes/1/551258.html|title=National Herald case: Bail in 5 minutes for Sonia Gandhi and Rahul, next hearing on February 20|publisher=[[India Today]]| date=19 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Sonia-Gandhi-Rahul-get-bail-in-National-Herald-case/articleshow/50244958.cms|title=Sonia Gandhi, Rahul get bail in National Herald case|publisher=[[The Times of India]]| date=19 December 2015}}</ref>
On 11 March 2016 the trial court allowed, after hearing Swamy's plea to examine balance sheets of INC, AJL and Young Indian<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/india/national-herald-case-delhi-hc-reserves-order-on-congress-plea_1877392.html|title=National Herald case: Delhi HC reserves order on Congress' plea|publisher=[[Zee News]]| date=18 April 2016}}</ref> from 2010 to 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/india/why-is-congress-so-afraid-of-national-herald-papers-will-re-apply-for-same-subramanian-swamy_1908050.html|title=Why is Congress so afraid of National Herald papers? Will re-apply for documents: Subramanian Swamy|publisher=[[Zee News]]| date=17 July 2016}}</ref> which was later overturned by the Delhi High Court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/national-herald-case-hc-sets-aside-trial-court-order-summoning-cong-documents/story-RFR00NE8KQeZNPXpvTgQFP.html|title=National Herald case: HC sets aside trial court order summoning Cong documents|publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]| date=12 July 2016}}</ref>
On 26 May 2018 Subramanian Swamy's application to the trial court seeking a directive for the defendants to verify material filed by Swamy in the National Herald case was denied. <ref>http://indianexpress.com/article/india/subramanian-swamy-application-in-national-herald-case-dismissed-by-delhi-court-5192605/lite/?</ref>

'''Of counsel''' is the [[title]] of an [[Lawyer|attorney]] in the [[legal profession]] of the [[United States]] who often has a relationship with a [[law firm]] or an organization but is neither an [[Associate attorney|associate]] nor [[Partner (business rank)|partner]]. Some firms use titles such as "counsel", "special counsel", and "senior counsel" for the same concept. According to [[American Bar Association]] Formal Opinion 90-357, the term "of counsel" is used to describe a "close, personal, continuous, and regular relationship" between the firm and counsel lawyer.<ref name="http://www.lacba.org/showpage.cfm?pageid=12424">{{cite web|title=County Bar Update|work=Los Angeles County Bar Association|accessdate=2013-04-15}}</ref> In large law firms, the title generally denotes a lawyer with the experience of a partner, but who does not carry the same workload or business development responsibility.<ref name="barnes">{{cite web|last1=Barnes|first1=Harrison|title=What Law Firm Titles Mean: Of Counsel, Non-Equity Partner, Equity Partner Explained|url=http://www.bcgsearch.com/article/900042747/What-Law-Firm-Titles-Mean-Of-Counsel-Non-Equity-Partner-Equity-Partner-Explained/|publisher=BCG Attorney Search|accessdate=2016-02-29}}</ref>
== American Bar Association definitions == Formal Opinion 90-357 of the American Bar Association provides four acceptable definitions of the term:<ref>{{cite web|title=Formal Opinion 90-357, May 10, 1990|url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/administrative/professional_responsibility/formal_opinion_90_357.authcheckdam.pdf|publisher=American Bar Association Standing Committee on Ethics and Professional Responsibility|accessdate=2016-02-29}}</ref>
*A part-time practitioner who practices law in association with a firm, but on a basis different from that of the mainstream lawyers in the firm. Such part-time practitioners are sometimes lawyers who have decided to change from a full-time practice, either with that firm or with another, to a part-time one, or who have changed careers entirely, as for example former judges or government officials, or attorneys who transition from corporate/in-house practice to law firm practice.
*A retired partner of a firm who, although not actively practicing law, nonetheless remains associated with it and available for occasional consultation.
*A lawyer who is, in effect, a probationary partner-to-be, usually brought in laterally with the expectation of becoming partner after a relatively short period of time.
*A permanent status in between associate and partner, having the quality of [[tenure]], or something close to it, but lacking an expectation of likely promotion to partner status.
== Typical situations == The title may be used in a number of situations, including:<ref name="barnes" />
*Lawyers who have useful experience for a firm (such as knowledge of a particular "niche" practice area) but do not generate enough business to warrant promotion to partnership.
*Senior lawyers seeking relatively low working hours, billable hours and revenue generation requirements.
*Lawyers transitioning from in-house{{what|date=October 2018}} or government roles.
== Other uses == Some firms also use the term to refer to attorneys hired on a temporary basis to assist with a particular case. However, because "of counsel" describes "a close, regular, personal relationship", temporary lawyers used by law firms to engage in document reviews for a specific project or for limited duration are not "of counsel".<ref>The Economics and Ethics of Hiring a Temporary Lawyer by Peter J. Gardner ("A temporary lawyer is not 'of counsel'"); Wisconsin Lawyer ("'Temporary lawyer' does not include a lawyer who has an 'of counsel' relationship with a law firm or who is retained in a matter as independent associated counsel"); National Association for Legal Career Professionals (separately defining "contract attorney/temporary attorney" as substantively distinct from "of counsel"); Washington State Bar Association (expressly distinguishing between "contract lawyer" and "of counsel"); Contract Lawyers in Kentucky (relying upon ABA Formal Opinion 88-356 in specifically distinguishing "contract lawyers" and "temporary lawyers" from the meaning "of counsel"); The Of Counsel Agreement: A Guide for the Law Firm and Practitioner ("the use of the title 'Of Counsel' is permissible . . . as long as the 'Of Counsel's' relationship with another lawyer or firm is close, regular and personal and the use of the title is not otherwise false or misleading," and among the arrangements specifically excluded from the use of this designation are where the attorney is involved in only "a single case" for the law firm or constitutes an "outside consultant").</ref>
==Compensation== The average annual base salary for “of counsel” in the United States between 2003 and 2009 was US$216,019 (with salary varying depending on size/reputation of the firm, its location, and the attorney’ experience).<ref>Authors unknown (2003 to 2009). Jobs-Salary.com: "A total of 18 real of counsel salary data listed. Salary Average: $216,019 Salary Range: $62,000 $400,000", ranging from 2003 to 2009. Retrieved from http://www.jobs-salary.com/of-counsel-salary.htm.</ref> At highly prestigious law firms, an "of counsel" may make as much as US$375,000 per year.<ref name="barnes" />

'''Permission culture''' is a term often employed by [[Lawrence Lessig]] and other [[Copyright reform movement|copyright activist]]s such as [[Luis Villa]]<ref>[http://lu.is/blog/2013/01/27/taking-post-open-source-seriously-as-a-statement-about-copyright-law/ Pushing back against licensing and the permission culture] on lu.is (2013)</ref> and [[Nina Paley]]<ref>[http://blog.ninapaley.com/2013/12/07/make-art-not-law-2/ make-art-not-law] on ninapaley.com (2013)</ref> to describe a [[society]] in which [[copyright]] restrictions are pervasive and enforced to the extent that any and all uses of copyrighted works need to be explicitly leased. This has both economic and social implications: in such a society, copyright holders could require payment for each use of a work and, perhaps more importantly, permission to make any sort of [[derivative work]].
Lawrence Lessig describes permission culture in contrast with [[free culture movement|free culture]]. While permission culture describes a society in which previous creators or those with power must grant people permission to use material, free culture ensures that anyone is able to create without restrictions from the past. An example Lessig cites in his book, ''[[Free Culture (book)|Free Culture]]'', is photography. In this example, if the legal environment surrounding the early stages of photography had been stricter with what constituted ownership and leaned more towards permission culture, photography would have developed in a drastically different manner and would be limited.<ref>Lessig, Lawrence. Free Culture. The Penguin Group, 2003.</ref>
An implication of permission culture is that creators are blocked by systemic procedures and this discourages innovation. Requiring permission in this sense means that creators will have to prove their usage of material is fair, even where legally unnecessary,<ref>{{cite web|title=Copyright, Creative Commons and other Calamities in Scientific Publishing|url=http://governancexborders.com/2015/05/10/copyright-creative-commons-and-other-calamities-in-scientific-publishing/|accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> which is a process that some would decide not to continue.<ref>{{cite web|last=Masnick |first=Mike |url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20101227/09520712421/permission-culture-automated-diminishment-fair-use.shtml |title=Permission Culture And The Automated Diminishment Of Fair Use |publisher=Techdirt |date=December 27, 2010 |accessdate=2012-11-15}}</ref>
This term is often contrasted with [[remix culture]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rimmer|first=Matthew|title=Digital Copyright and the Consumer Revolution: Hands Off My iPod|year=2007|publisher=Elgar|location=Cheltenham, UK [u.a.]|isbn=978-1-84542-948-5|pages=261–262|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1ONyncVruj8C&lpg=PA261&dq=%22permission%20culture%22%20remix%20culture&pg=PA261#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>

A '''proxy firm''' (also a proxy advisor, proxy adviser, proxy voting agency, vote service provider or shareholder voting research provider) provides services to shareholders (in most cases an [[institutional investor]] of some type) to vote their shares at shareholder meetings of, usually, quoted companies.
The typical services provided include agenda translation, provision of vote management software, voting policy development, company research, and vote administration including vote execution. According to their websites, not all firms provide voting recommendations and those that do may simply execute client voting instructions.
The votes executed are called "Proxy Votes" because the shareholder usually does not attend the meeting and instead sends instructions - a proxy appointment - for a third party, usually the chairman of the meeting to vote shares in accordance with the instructions given on the voting card.
==Global industry== Firms in the industry include:
*'''[http://www.ejproxy.com/ Egan-Jones Proxy Services]''' (USA) <ref>{{cite web|last1=McRitchie|first1=James|title=Egan-Jones Proxy Services Acquires ProxyTell|url=http://corpgov.net/2014/05/egan-jones-proxy-services-acquires-proxytell/|website=corpgov.net|publisher=CorpGov.net|accessdate=14 June 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Glass Lewis|Glass, Lewis & Co]]''' (USA) *InGovern Research Services (IN)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.corpgov.net/2012/03/pai-backs-indias-ingovern-proxy-service/|title=Pai Backs India's InGovern Proxy Service|last=McRitchie|first=James|date=March 3, 2012|work=CorpGov.net|access-date=July 19, 2017|archive-url=https://www.corpgov.net/2012/03/pai-backs-indias-ingovern-proxy-service/|archive-date=July 19, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.corpgov.net/2012/08/indian-mutual-funds-need-to-improve-proxy-voting-policies-and-practices/|title=Indian Mutual Funds Need to Improve Proxy Voting Policies and Practices|last=McRitchie|first=James|date=August 9, 2012|work=CorpGov.net|access-date=July 19, 2017|archive-url=https://www.corpgov.net/2012/08/indian-mutual-funds-need-to-improve-proxy-voting-policies-and-practices/|archive-date=July 19, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> *'''[[Institutional Investor Advisory Services]]''' India Limited (IiAS) (IN) *'''[[Institutional Shareholder Services]]''' (USA) <ref>Part of [[Egan-Jones Ratings Company]],{{cite web|url=http://www.cfo.com/article.cfm/9253594?f=related|title=Proxy Firms Fire Back at Critics|author=Harris, Roy|publisher=CFO.com|date=2007-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=J. de la Merced|first1=Michael|title=Vestar to Buy I.S.S., an Influential Shareholder Adviser|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/18/vestar-to-buy-i-s-s-an-influential-shareholder-adviser/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|accessdate=14 June 2014|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> *'''[[Www.sesgovernance.com|Stakeholders Empowerment Services]]'''<ref>Stakeholders Empowerment Services - India's 1st non-profit Corporate Governance Advisory firm. Stakeholders Empowerment Services is a Corporate Governance research and advisory firm. It is the first Company to register as Proxy Advisor under SEBI.</ref> '''(SES) (IN)
According to their websites, most industry participants offer global coverage.
== Controversial role== The role of proxy firms has come under considerable scrutiny in recent years, most notably from the US corporate lobby.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/controversy-ignites-competition-among-proxy/story.aspx?guid=BD711286-71DE-4D3B-939F-9C6B9F1BC100|title=Controversy ignites competition among proxy firms|author=Alistair Barr & Jonathan Burton|publisher=Marketwatch|date=2007-06-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dent|first=George W.|date=2014-01-01|title=A Defense of Proxy Advisors|ssrn=2451240|location=Rochester, NY|publisher=Social Science Research Network}}</ref>
In 2013, the US Securities and Exchange Commission fined ISS $300,000 for revealing non-public information in respect of clients proxy votes<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/News/PressRelease/Detail/PressRelease/1365171574952|title=SEC.gov {{!}} SEC Charges Institutional Shareholder Services in Breach of Clients' Confidential Proxy Voting Information|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref>
== Conflicts of interest == A potential conflict of interest identified by the [[Government Accountability Office]] is that some owners of proxy firms do business with both issuers and investors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guerdonassociates.com/News-Detail.asp?cid=&navID=&NewsID=198|title=The influence of proxy advisory firms on executive remuneration|date=2007-01-10|publisher=Guerdon Associates}}</ref> Analysis of executive remuneration, or executive pay, is a notable feature of the work of shareholder voting research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloggingstocks.com/2008/01/15/proxy-firm-questions-tyson-chiefs-pay/|title=Proxy firm questions Tyson chief's pay|author=Zac Bissonnette|date=2008-01-15}}</ref> Some policymakers believe that increasing competition in the industry may improve service quality. For example, in 2010 a Securities & Exchange Commission consultation document asked whether certain issues in the proxy advisory industry, including conflicts of interest, are affected by limited competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/rules/concept/2010/34-62495.pdf|title=Proxy Plumbing Concept Release}}</ref>
==Code of conduct== Following a number of regulatory reviews by securities regulators, including the Canadian Securities Administrators<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.securities-administrators.ca/aboutcsa.aspx?id=1348|title=Canadian Securities Administrators Publish Guidance for Proxy Advisory Firms|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.esma.europa.eu/databases-library/esma-library/proxy%2520advisor|title=ESMA LIBRARY|website=www.esma.europa.eu|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref> a number of firms have published a Code of Conduct: the Best Practice Principles for Shareholder Voting Research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bppgrp.info/|title=Best Practice Principles for Shareholder Voting Research|date=2014}}</ref> The Code was developed with an independent chairman, Dr Dirk Zetsche, Propter Homines Chair for Banking and Securities law at the Institute for Financial Services of the University of Liechtenstein and Director of the Center for Business & Corporate Law at Heinrich Heine University in Duesseldorf/Germany.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://corpgov.law.harvard.edu/2014/06/10/best-practice-principles-for-proxy-advisors-and-chairmans-report/|title=Best Practice Principles for Proxy Advisors and Chairman's Report|website=corpgov.law.harvard.edu|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

A '''Request For Evidence''' ('''RFE'''), is a request issued by the [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]] to petitioners for residency, citizenship, family visas, and employment visas. Examples of petitions for which a RFE may be issued are [[Form I-129]] (alien worker authorization), [[Form I-140]] (immigrant worker authorization), and [[Form I-130]] (family visas).<ref name=2005-memo/><ref name=2013-memo/>
== Situations where it is used ==
The RFE is intended for use in cases where the adjudicator (the person evaluating the petition) believes that there is not enough evidence to approve the petition, but also believes that the petition may be redeemable, and that there is no clear factual or statutory basis for denial.<ref name=2013-memo>{{cite web|url = http://www.uscis.gov/sites/default/files/USCIS/Laws/Memoranda/2013/June%202013/Requests%20for%20Evidence%20%28Final%29.pdf|title = Policy Memorandum|date = June 3, 2013|accessdate = January 16, 2016|publisher = [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]]}}</ref>
The RFE, when used, should be as clear as possible about what types of additional evidence are needed to fill in the gap, and what inconsistencies or problems have been found in the evidence submitted so far. It is not intended for use for the adjudicator's reassurance in cases where there is enough evidence to approve the petition.<ref name=2005-memo>{{cite web|url = http://www.uscis.gov/sites/default/files/USCIS/Laws/Memoranda/Static_Files_Memoranda/Archives%201998-2008/2005/rfe021605.pdf|title = Interoffice Memorandum|publisher = [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]]|date = February 16, 2005|accessdate = January 16, 2016}}</ref>
The RFE is sent to, and the response must be sent by, the petitioner (or the attorney representing the petitioner, in cases where the petition is filed through an attorney) rather than the beneficiary.
== Related communications ==
=== Differences with NOID ===
The following are some key differences between the RFE and the [[Notice of Intent to Deny]] (NOID):<ref name=2005-memo/><ref name=2013-memo/>
* ''Likelihood of denial'': The RFE is issued when there is significant uncertainty about whether the petition will be approved, whereas the NOID is generally used when a denial is quite likely. * ''Accompanying information'': A RFE comes with a list of additional types of evidence needed. A NOID comes equipped with a list of reasons for denial. While the two lists are somewhat related (insofar as a reason for denial translates to a piece of evidence that could overturn the denial) they have different framings. * ''Time given to respond'': The time given to respond to a RFE is generally greater than that for a NOID.
=== Request for clarification ===
In cases where the USCIS simply needs answers to a few specific questions (such as a complete translation), it simply issues a Request for Clarification instead of a RFE.<ref name=2005-memo/>
== Tips for avoiding RFEs ==
Submitting clear and complete documentation in the petition itself can minimize the need for RFEs. The USCIS website offers the following tips to avoid RFEs:<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.uscis.gov/working-united-states/permanent-workers/employment-based-immigration-fifth-preference-eb-5/general-tips-evidence|title = General Tips for Evidence|publisher = [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]]|date = March 3, 2015|accessdate = January 16, 2016}}</ref>
* '''Inconsistencies in documents''' should be explained and evidence to reconcile the incosistencies should be included. * '''Unavailability of documents''' should be explained with clear evidence. * '''Probative value''': Some kinds of documents are considered more authoritative and have more probative value. For instance, income tax returns have more probative value than letters from family or friends. * '''Incomplete translations''' should be avoided. Any documents being submitted in a language other than English must be translated in their entirety.
== Types of evidence requested ==
RFEs typically request one or more of the following types of evidence: * ability of employer to pay * periods of current or prior stay in the United States * prior work experience * educational details or evaluation * documents supporting claims of exceptional ability or outstanding research
== Response protocol ==
The time within which the response to a RFE must be sent is indicated on the RFE. It generally varies between 30 and 90 days. If no response is received within the time indicated on the RFE, the USCIS will process the application without considering the additional evidence, which in most cases means a denial (because petitions where there was enough evidence to accept should not have RFEs in the first place).<ref>{{cite web|title=Policy Memorandum: Requests for Evidence and Notices of Intent to Deny|url=https://www.uscis.gov/sites/default/files/USCIS/Laws/Memoranda/2013/June%202013/Requests%20for%20Evidence%20%28Final%29.pdf|website=USCIS|publisher=United States Citizenship & Immigration Services|accessdate=20 March 2018|date=3 June 2013}}</ref>
The petitioner has only one chance to respond to a RFE,<ref>{{cite web|title=Adjudicator's Field Manual, Sec. 10.3 General Adjudication Procedures|url=https://www.uscis.gov/ilink/docView/AFM/HTML/AFM/0-0-0-1/0-0-0-1067/0-0-0-1166.html|website=USCIS|publisher=United States Citizenship & Immigration Services|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref>
* The petitioner can submit all the requested evidence. * The petitioner can "partially respond" by submitting some of the requested evidence. The USCIS will use the partial submission along with the earlier submission to evaluate the petition. * The petitioner can choose not to respond, so a final decision will be based on the original petition. This usually means a denial. * The petitioner can withdraw the petition.
When responding to a RFE, the petitioner may attach additional pieces of evidence over and above those explicitly requested in the RFE.
== Relation with processing timeline ==
The expected processing time for petitions is generally defined as the time till an approval, denial, RFE, or NOID is issued. Therefore, the time taken while waiting for a response from the petitioner is not counted as part of the processing time. After the petitioner responds, the expected additional processing time is comparable with the processing time for a complete first application.
For petitions that request the [[Premium Processing Service]], the expected processing time to a first response (approval, denial, RFE, or NOID) is 15 days, and the time after receiving a response to the RFE is another 15 days.<ref name=uscis-premium-processing>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscis.gov/forms/how-do-i-use-premium-processing-service|title = How Do I Use the Premium Processing Service?|publisher = [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]]|accessdate = April 4, 2015}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Notice of Intent to Deny]] * [[Notice of Intent to Revoke]] * [[USCIS processing times]]

{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = San Diego County Public Defender’s Office |type = office |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = Seal of the San Diego Public Defender.jpg |seal_width = 160px |seal_caption = Seal of the Public Defender — County of San Diego |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = {{Start date|1988}} |preceding1 = |jurisdiction = [[Government of San Diego County]] |headquarters = Administrative Office
450 B Street, Suite 1100
[[San Diego, California]], 92101 |region_code = US |coordinates = |motto = |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = Randy Mize |chief1_position = Public Defender |child2_agency = |keydocument1 = |website = [http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/public_defender.html Public Defender’s Office website] |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''San Diego County Public Defender''''s office is an agency of the [[government of San Diego County, California]]. It provides [[Legal aid|legal assistance]] to individuals charged with a crime in state court who are financially unable to retain private counsel.{{cite web|title=San Diego County Public Defender Website|url=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/public_defender/|website=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/|accessdate=28 January 2015}} The office consists of the Primary Public Defender, the Alternate Public Defender, the Office of Assigned Counsel & the Multiple Conflicts Office. Mental health and juvenile court matters are handled by special units within the divisions. Courts within their jurisdiction include the [[California Superior Court|San Diego Superior Court]], the [[California Courts of Appeal|California Court of Appeal]] for the [[California Court of Appeal for the Fourth District|Fourth District]], and the [[Supreme Court of California|California Supreme Court]]. The [[San Diego County District Attorney]] and the San Diego City Attorney prosecute alleged [[felony]] and [[misdemeanor]] violations of [[California]] [[state law]] that occur within the jurisdiction of [[San Diego County]]. Alleged [[federal law]] violations by indigent defendants are defended by the Federal Defenders of San Diego Inc. ==History== The San Diego County Public Defender's Office was established in 1988 by a [[San Diego County]] resolution. The Alternate Public Defender was established by the Board of Supervisors in 1990.{{cite web|title=San Diego Alternate Public Defender|url=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/apd/|website=www.sandiegocounty.gov|accessdate=28 January 2015}} In 2005, the Multiple Conflicts Office - Major Cases (MCO) was created to represent people who are charged with complicated and serious cases throughout San Diego County and who are financially unable to retain private counsel.{{cite web|title=MCO PD|url=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/MCO_PD.html|website=www.sandiegocounty.gov|accessdate=28 January 2015}} In 2009, the County of San Diego consolidated separate [[indigent defense]] offices—Public Defender, Alternate Public Defender, Office of Assigned Counsel, Juvenile Delinquency & Multiple Conflict Office—into one office. The office formed a Public Defender Community Outreach Program that strives to connect with partners in San Diego communities to enrich the lives of those less fortunate and assist in securing equal access to justice.{{cite web|title=SD PD Outreach Program - About Us|url=http://www.pd-outreach.org/about-us.aspx|website=pd-outreach.org|accessdate=28 January 2015}} In 1994, San Diego County Public Defenders Kathleen Coyne and Susan Clemens were awarded Public Defender of the Year by the California Public Defender's Association for their work defending Dale Akiki in the [[Faith Chapel Church ritual abuse case]]. Several San Diego County Public Defenders have gone on to become judges in [[California Superior Court]].{{cite web|last1=Perry|first1=Tony|title=Four named San Diego County judges, including son of slain drug agent|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-san-diego-judges-20140716-story.html|website=latimes.com|accessdate=28 January 2015}} In 2014, the office filed over 5,000 petitions—after [[Proposition 47 (2014)]]—to have felony convictions and sentences reduced.{{cite web|last1=Tagharobi|first1=Sherene|title=Prop 47: Nearly 5000 Petitions for Early Release Submitted in San Diego|website=nbcsandiego.com|accessdate=28 January 2015}} ==Primary Public Defender== The San Diego County Primary Public Defender (PPD) provides the majority of indigent defense services in [[San Diego County]]. The Primary Public Defender has five offices in the County: [[downtown San Diego]], [[Vista, California|Vista]] (North County), [[Chula Vista, California|Chula Vista]] (South Bay), [[El Cajon, California|El Cajon]] (East County), and a Juvenile Office.{{cite web|title=SD Public Defender Locations|url=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/public_defender/locations.html|website=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/|accessdate=28 January 2015}} ==Alternate Public Defender== The APD is responsible for defending those cases where the Primary Public Defender has a conflict of interest or is unable to defend the individual for various reasons. The Office of the Alternate Public Defender has two divisions. The Adult Criminal Division—operating out of all APD locations—represents indigent persons accused of a crime. The Juvenile Delinquency Division—out of [[Kearny Mesa]]—represents minors accused of truancy or criminal offenses. The Alternate Public Defender maintains offices in downtown San Diego, El Cajon, South Bay, Vista, and Kearny Mesa. ==Multiple Conflicts Office - Major Cases== The Multiple Conflicts Office - Major Cases (MCO) accepts court appointments that the Public Defender and the Alternate Public Defender are unable to accept due to a [[conflict of interest]] or other order of the court. MCO represents people who are charged with only the most complicated and serious cases throughout San Diego County. MCO attorneys possess many years of experience and training for the most serious types of criminal cases. The MCO is an independent and ethically separate division of the Department of the Public Defender and does not share client information or otherwise interact with attorneys from other divisions on the same case. ==Office of Assigned Counsel== If a court finds that the PPD and APD have a [[conflict of interest]], then Office of Assigned Counsel (OAC) will provide the indigent [[defendant]] with a private practitioner who has been pre-screened and placed on a panel managed by the OAC.{{cite web|title=Intern, Clerkship & Volunteers|url=http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/public_defender/Volunteers.html|accessdate=2 February 2015}} ==See also== * [[California Courts of Appeal]] (Fourth District, Division 1) * [[California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation]] * [[California Superior Court]] * [[California Supreme Court]] * [[Chula Vista Police Department]] * [[El Cajon Police Department]] * [[Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility]] * [[San Diego County District Attorney]] * [[San Diego County, California Probation]] * [[San Diego County Sheriff's Department]] * [[San Diego Police Department]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{San Diego County}} {{San Diego Metropolitan Area}} {{San Diego-Tijuana}} {{San Diego-Imperial (California)}} {{California}} {{USLargestMetros}} {{Coord|33.02|-116.77|display=title|type:adm2nd_region:US-CA_source:UScensus1990}} [[Category:Government of San Diego County, California]] [[Category:Legal aid]] [[Category:Criminal defense organizations]]

{{Infobox treaty |name = Sino-Portuguese Treaty of Peking |long_name = Treaty of Friendship and Commerce between Portugal and China |image = Treaty of Peking1887.jpg |image_width = |caption = |date_signed = 1 December 1887 |location_signed = [[Peking]] (Beijing), China |date_effective = 28 April 1888 |condition_effective = Exchange of ratifications |signatories = *{{flagicon|Portugal|1830}} Tomas de Sousa Rosa *{{flagicon image|Flag of the Qing Dynasty (1862-1889).svg|border=no}} [[Prince Ch'ing]] *{{flagicon image|Flag of the Qing Dynasty (1862-1889).svg|border=no}} Sun Iu-uen |parties = *{{flagicon|Portugal|1830}} [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portugal]] *{{flagicon image|Flag of the Qing Dynasty (1862-1889).svg|border=no}} [[Qing dynasty|China]] |languages = Portuguese and Chinese |wikisource = }} {{Chinese|t=中葡和好通商條約|j=zung1 pou4 wo4 hou2 tung1 soeng1 tiu4 joek3|p=zhong1 pu2 he2 hao3 tong1 shang1 tiao2 yue1|t2=中葡里斯本草約|j2=zung1 pou1 lei5 si1 bun2 cou2 joek3|p2=zhong1 pu2 li3 si4 ben3 cao3 yue1|por=Tratado de Amizade e Comércio Sino-Português}} The '''Sino-Portuguese Treaty of Peking''' was a trade treaty between the [[Kingdom of Portugal]] and the [[Qing dynasty]] of China, signed on 1 December 1887. It is counted by the Chinese as among the [[Unequal treaty|unequal treaties]]. == Background == On 13 August 1862, China and Portugal signed the Treaty of Friendship and Trade in [[Tianjin|Tientsin]] (Tianjin). The treaty was largely a trade agreement but it also defined [[Portuguese Macau|Macau]]'s political and juridical statue, although it did not directly mention the issue of Portuguese sovereignty.Mendes, Carmen Amado (2013). ''Portugal, China and the Macau Negotiations, 1986-1999''. Hong Kong University Press. pp. 11–12. {{ISBN|9789888139002}} . It contained two clauses regarding Macau's status: Article II annulled earlier agreements and referred to Macau as "formerly in the Province of [[Guangdong|Canton]]", while Article III recognised the status of a "Governor General of Macao". However, China did not ratify the treaty and it become void in 1864.Ride, Lindsay; Ride, May (1989). ''The Voices of Macao Stones''. Hong Kong University Press. pp. 54–56. {{ISBN|9622094872}}. In June 1886, a joint Sino-British commission advised that the administrative responsibility for controlling the import of opium into China should be transferred from the [[Hoppo]] in [[Guangzhou|Canton]] (Guangzhou) to the Chinese [[Imperial Maritime Customs Service]]. Although Britain and China agreed to this, it could not be fully successful without Portuguese involvement. In 1887, China sent a diplomatic mission to [[Lisbon]], which included James Campbell, a senior British member of the service, representing the superintendent of the customs service [[Sir Robert Hart, 1st Baronet|Sir Robert Hart]]. On 26 March 1887, Campbell and Portuguese Foreign Minister [[Henrique de Barros Gomes]] signed the four-point Lisbon Protocol:[[William Frederick Mayers|Mayers, William Frederick]] (1902). ''[https://archive.org/stream/cu31924023464278#page/n177/mode/2up Treaties Between the Empire of China and Foreign Powers]'' (4th ed.). Shanghai: North-China Herald. pp. 156–157.
Art. 1st.—A Treaty of friendship and commerce with the [[most favoured nation]] clause will be concluded and signed at [[Peking]]. Art. 2nd.—China confirms perpetual occupation and government of Macao and its dependencies by Portugal, as any other Portuguese possession. Art. 3rd.—Portugal engages never to alienate Macao and its dependencies without agreement with China. Art. 4th.—Portugal engages to co-operate in opium revenue work at Macao in the same way as England at [[British Hong Kong|Hong Kong]].
== Terms == Portugal followed up on this agreement by sending an envoy to Peking (Beijing), where a treaty of amity and commerce based on the protocol was drawn up. On 1 December 1887, the Treaty of Peking was signed by Chinese representatives [[Prince Ch'ing]] and Sun Iu-uen, and Tomas de Sousa Rosa for Portugal on 1 December 1887. It contained 54 articles and was ratified on 28 April 1888. Articles II and III stated:
II. China confirms, in its entirety, the second Article of the Protocol of Lisbon, relating to the perpetual occupation and government of Macao by Portugal. III. Portugal confirms, in its entirety, the third Article of the Protocol of Lisbon, relating to the engagement never to alienate Macao without previous agreement with China.
According to the Portuguese interpretation, sovereignty over Macau was surrendered to Portugal. In the Chinese interpretation, only administrative rights were transferred. == Aftermath == After December 1887, issues related to rent payments and the presence of a Chinese custom house or resident [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|mandarin]] in Macau became irrelevant outside of academic interest. The early 20th century marked a new era for both countries, with [[1910 revolution|Portugal's 1910]] and [[1911 revolution|China's 1911]] republican revolutions establishing new governments. A growing nationalist movement in China voiced disapproval of the treaty and questioned its validity. These contentions manifested themselves in the unresolved topic of Macau's border demarcation. Although the Nationalist ([[Kuomintang]]) government in China vowed to abrogate the "[[Unequal treaty|unequal treaties]]", Macau's status remained unchanged. The 1928 Sino-Portuguese Treaty of Friendship and Trade reaffirmed Portuguese administration over Macau.Chan, Ming K. (2003). "[https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/2cf9/860dfb7365dd9b5349b3e3bcafdb4a50ea75.pdf Different Roads to Home: the retrocession of Hong Kong and Macau to Chinese sovereignty]". ''Journal of Contemporary China'' '''12''' (36): 497–499. In 1945, after the [[Sino-British New Equal Treaty|end of extraterritorial rights]] in China, the Nationalists called for the liquidation of foreign control over Hong Kong and Macau, but they were too preoccupied in the [[Chinese Civil War]] with the Communists to fulfil their goals of a "rights recovery" campaign.Cohen, Jerome Alan; Chiu, Hungdah (1974). ''People's China and International Law: A Documentary Study''. Vol. 1. Princeton University Press. p. 374. {{ISBN|9780691618692}}. After the [[Carnation Revolution|1974 Revolution]] in Portugal, a new decolonisation policy paved the way for Macau's retrocession to the People's Republic of China (PRC). Portugal offered to withdraw from Macau in late 1974, but China declined the offer in favour of a later time because it sought to preserve international and local confidence in Hong Kong, which was still under British rule, and also because it prioritised the reunification of Taiwan. In January 1975, Portugal recognised the PRC as the sole legitimate government of China and ended ties with the Nationalists in [[Taipei]]. In 1976, Portugal unilaterally changed the legal designation of Macau from a "colony" to "territory under Portuguese administration".Chan, Ming K.; Chan, Shiu-hing Lo (2006). ''The A to Z of the Hong Kong SAR and the Macao SAR''. Plymouth: Scarecrow Press. p. 283. {{ISBN|9780810876330}}. In 1987, the [[Sino-Portuguese Joint Declaration]] was signed and Macau became a "Chinese territory under Portuguese administration".Oliveira, Jorge; Cardinal, Paulo, eds. (2009). ''One Country, Two Systems, Three Legal Orders - Perspectives of Evolution: Essays on Macau's Autonomy after the Resumption of Sovereignty by China''. Berlin: Springer-Verlag. pp. 225–226. {{ISBN|9783540685722}}. On 20 December 1999—two years after the [[handover of Hong Kong]]—Macau was [[Transfer of sovereignty over Macau|returned to Chinese rule]].Page, Melvin Eugene. Sonnenburg, Penny M. (2003). ''Colonialism: An International, Social, Cultural, and Political Encyclopedia''. ABC-CLIO. p 359. {{ISBN|978-1-57607-335-3}}. == See also == * [[History of Macau]] * [[Western imperialism in Asia]] == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == *Tam, Camões (1994). "[http://www.icm.gov.mo/rc/viewer/20019/1014 The Sino-Portuguese Dispute over the Holder of Sovereignty of Macao and the Friendship and Trade Treaty Between China and Portugal from an International Law Perspective]". ''Review of Culture''. No. 19 (2nd series). Cultural Institute of Macao. == External links == *[http://ebook.lib.hku.hk/CADAL/B3364956X/ Full text of the treaty] {{DEFAULTSORT:Sino-Portuguese Treaty Of Peking}} [[Category:1887 in China]] [[Category:1887 in Portugal]] [[Category:1887 treaties]] [[Category:China–Portugal relations]] [[Category:Portuguese Macau]] [[Category:Treaties of the Kingdom of Portugal]] [[Category:Treaties of the Qing dynasty]] [[Category:Unequal treaties]] [[Category:December 1887 events]]

'''Soft intellectual property''' is sometimes used to refer to [[trademark]]s, [[copyright]], [[design rights]] and [[passing off]], in contrast to "hard intellectual property", which is sometimes used to refer to patents.<ref> [http://www.lawcareers.net/Solicitors/Specialisations/ipit.aspx ''Specialisations: IP''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916171049/http://www.lawcareers.net/Solicitors/Specialisations/ipit.aspx |date=2008-09-16 }}, Law Careers.net. Consulted on March 14, 2009. </ref><ref> ip4inno web site, [http://www.ip4inno.eu/index.php?id=203 ''Topic Browser'']. Consulted on March 14, 2009.</ref> Use of this phrase is controversial among IP practitioners.<ref>[[Eric Goldman]], [http://blog.ericgoldman.org/archives/2013/01/a_phrase_to_ret.htm ''Let's Stop Using the Term “Soft IP,”''] Technology & Marketing Law Blog, Jan. 8, 2013</ref>
The phrase "soft intellectual property" or ''Soft IP'' also refers to a system for licensing patents proposed in 2008. See [[Soft IP]].
In Semiconductors industry the term has a different meaning described at [[Semiconductor_intellectual_property_core#Types_of_IP_cores|Types of IP cores]]

[[Category:Intellectual property law]]

{{Distinguish|rolling election}}
In '''staggered elections''', not all places in an elected body are up for election at the same time. For example, United States [[Senate of the United States|Senators]] have a six-year term, but they are not all elected at the same time. Rather, elections are held every two years for [[Classes of United States Senators|one-third of Senate seats]].
Staggered elections have the effect of limiting control of a representative body by the body being represented, but can also minimize the impact of [[cumulative voting]].<ref>http://www.stroock.com/SiteFiles/Pub341.pdf</ref>
Many [[companies]] use staggered elections as a tool to prevent [[takeover]] attempts. Some legislative bodies (most commonly [[upper house]]s) use staggered elections, as do some public bodies, such as the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]].
==Application in business== A '''staggered board of directors''' or '''classified board''' is a prominent practice in [[US corporate law]] governing the [[board of directors]] of a [[company]], [[corporation]], or other organization, in which only a fraction (often one third) of the members of the board of directors is elected each time instead of en masse (where all directors have one-year terms). Each group of directors falls within a specified "class"—e.g., Class I, Class II, etc.—hence the use of the term "classified" board.<ref>See Faleye,O., 2007, Classified Boards, Firm value, and [[Management entrenchment|Managerial Entrenchment]], Journal of Financial Economics83, 501-529.</ref>
In publicly held companies, staggered boards have the effect of making hostile [[takeover]] attempts more difficult. When a board is staggered, hostile bidders must win more than one [[proxy fight]] at successive shareholder meetings in order to exercise control of the target [[corporation|firm]]. Particularly in combination with a [[poison pill]], a staggered board that cannot be dismantled or evaded is one of the most potent takeover defenses available to U.S. companies.<ref>See [[Lucian Bebchuk]], John C. Coates IV, and Guhan Subramanian, The Powerful Antitakeover Force of Staggered Boards: Theory, Evidence, and Policy, 54 Stan. L. Rev. 887 (2002).</ref>
In corporate [[cumulative voting]] systems, staggering has two basic effects: it makes it more difficult for minorities to elect directors, as the fewer directorships up for election requires a larger per cent of the equity to win; and it makes takeover attempts less likely to succeed as it is harder to vote in a majority of new directors.<ref name="corpfinance">{{cite book|last1=Hillier|first1=David|last2=Ross|first2=Stephen|last3=Westerfield|first3=Randolph|last4=Jaffe|first4=Jeffrey|last5=Jordan|first5=Bradford|title=Corporate Finance|date=2013|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|location=Berkshire|isbn=9780077139148|pages=34–35|edition=2nd European}}</ref> Staggering may also however serve a more beneficial purpose, that is provide "institutional memory" — continuity in the board of directors — which may be significant for corporations with long-range projects and plans.<ref name="corpfinance"/>
Institutional shareholders are increasingly calling for an end to staggered boards of directors—also called "declassifying" the boards. ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported in January 2007 that 2006 marked a key switch in the trend toward declassification or annual votes on all directors: more than half (55%) of the S&P 500 companies have declassified boards, compared with 47% in 2005.<ref>Jared A. Favole, "Big Firms Increasingly Declassify Boards", The Wall Street Journal, Jan. 10, 2007.</ref>
==Legislative bodies which use staggered elections== ===National===
* [[Argentine Chamber of Deputies|Chamber of Deputies of Argentina]] * [[Argentine Senate|Senate of Argentina]] * [[Rajya Sabha|Rajya Sabha (India)]] * [[Senate of Australia]] * [[Senate of Brazil]] * [[Senate of the Czech Republic]] * [[Senate of France]] * [[House of Councillors (Japan)|House of Councillors of Japan]] * [[Senate of Pakistan]] * [[Senate of the Philippines]] * [[United States Senate]]
===State=== ====Argentina====
12 of the 24 provincial legislatures have staggered elections:
*[[Buenos Aires Province|Buenos Aires]]: Chamber of Deputies and Senate *[[Buenos Aires City]]: [[Unicameral]] legislature *[[Catamarca Province|Catamarca]]: Chamber of Deputies and Senate *[[Chaco Province|Chaco]]: Unicameral legislature *[[Corrientes Province|Corrientes]]: Chamber of Deputies and Senate *[[Formosa Province|Formosa]]: Unicameral legislature *[[Jujuy Province|Jujuy]]: Unicameral legislature *[[La Rioja Province, Argentina|La Rioja]]: Unicameral legislature *[[Mendoza Province|Mendoza]]: Chamber of Deputies and Senate *[[Misiones Province|Misiones]]: Unicameral legislature *[[Salta Province|Salta]]: Chamber of Deputies and Senate *[[San Luis Province|San Luis]]: Chamber of Deputies and Senate
====Australia==== Three of Australia's five State Legislative Councils use staggered elections: * [[New South Wales Legislative Council]] * [[South Australian Legislative Council]] * [[Tasmanian Legislative Council]]
[[Local government in Western Australia|Local councils in Western Australia]] also have staggered elections.<ref>[https://www.elections.wa.gov.au/elections/local "Local Government Elections"], ''[[Western Australian Electoral Commission]]''.</ref>
====United States==== 27 of the State Senates in the United States have staggered elections:<ref>[https://ballotpedia.org/Length_of_terms_of_state_senators "Length of terms of state senators"], Ballotpedia, Accessed 24 August 2016.</ref> * [[Alaska State Senate]] * [[Arkansas State Senate]] * [[California State Senate]] * [[Colorado State Senate]] * [[Delaware State Senate]] * [[Florida State Senate]] * [[Hawaii State Senate]] * [[Illinois State Senate]] * [[Indiana State Senate]] * [[Iowa Senate]] * [[Kentucky State Senate]] * [[Missouri State Senate]] * [[Montana State Senate]] * [[Nebraska State Senate]] * [[Nevada State Senate]] * [[North Dakota State Senate]] * [[Ohio State Senate]] * [[Oklahoma State Senate]] * [[Oregon State Senate]] * [[Pennsylvania State Senate]] * [[Tennessee State Senate]] * [[Texas State Senate]] * [[Utah State Senate]] * [[Washington State Senate]] * [[West Virginia State Senate]] * [[Wisconsin State Senate]] * [[Wyoming State Senate]]
===Local=== * Some local councils in the [[United Kingdom]]
==Historical usage== ===National=== * [[General Council of Andorra]] (1867–1979)<ref name='andorra'>[http://www.consellgeneral.ad/fitxers/documents/dia-de-la-democracia-2016/labstencio-al-principat-dandorra Consell General - L'abstenció al Principat d'Andorra]</ref> * [[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber of Representatives]] and [[Senate of Belgium]] (1835–1919)<ref>[http://www.elections.fgov.be/index.php?id=2101 Direction des élections - Evolution de la législation électorale]</ref> * [[Senate of Bolivia|Senate]] and [[Chamber of Deputies of Bolivia]] (1944–1964) * [[Legislative Assembly of Costa Rica]] (1913–1948) * Senate and Chamber of Representatives of [[Cuba]] (1902–1950) * [[Landstinget (Denmark)|Landsting of Denmark]] (1915–1953)<ref>[http://www.dst.dk/Site/Dst/Udgivelser/GetPubFile.aspx?id=20213&sid=rigsvalg Danmarks Statistik - Rigsdagsvalgene og folkeafstemningerne i april og maj 1953, p. 182]</ref> * [[National Assembly (Ecuador)|National Assembly of Ecuador]] (1945–1970, 1984–1998) * [[National Congress of Honduras]] (until 1942) * [[Chamber of Deputies (Luxembourg)|Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg]] (1922–1951) * Senate and Congress of [[Nicaragua]] (1912–1932) * [[Första kammaren|First Chamber of Sweden]] (1867–1970)

A '''testamentary disposition''' is any gift of any [[property]] by a testator under the terms of a [[will (law)|will]].
==Types== Types of testamentary dispositions include: * [[Gift (law)]], assets that have been legally transferred from one person to another * [[Will (law)|Legacy]], testamentary gift of personal property, traditionally of money but may be real or personal property * [[Life estate]], a concept used in common and statutory law to designate the ownership of land for the duration of a person's life * Demonstrative legacy, a gift of a specific sum of money with a direction that is to be paid out of a particular fund
==See also== *[[Testator]]
